clinical_study.brief_title: A Pilot Study of Constraint Induced Movement Therapy in Preschool Cerebral Palsy After Botulism Toxin Injection
clinical_study.official_title: The Pilot Study of Constraint Induced Movement Therapy(CIMT） Intervention in Children With Hemiplegic Cerebral Palsy After Botulism Toxin Injection in Preschool Education

brief_summary.textblock: To establish a pilot randomized, crossover study on applying 2 constraint-induced movement therapy (CIMT) interventions in children with hemiplegic cerebral palsy after botulinum toxin injection during preschool education.

detailed_description.textblock: This study was designed to be a pilot study on the use of 4-week 2-hours/day and 2-week 4-hours/day CIMT interventions in children with hemiplegic CP after a BoNT-A injection in preschool education, and compared the effects and psychological stress of CP children relative to the 2 CIMT programs.

arm_group.description: a 4-week 2-hours/day constraint program, total 40 hours CIMT, in preschool education.
one was a 2-week 4-hours/day constraint program, total 40 hours CIMT, in preschool education.

intervention.description: Participants were randomly allocated to 1 of 2 CIMT programs (40 hours): a 2-week 4-hours/day CIMT program and a 4-week 2-hours/day CIMT program. One CIMT program was performed 1 month after a BoNT-A injection, and then the second program was implemented with the next injection.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
hemiplegic or quadriplegic CP children were under a regular rehabilitation program with BoNT-A injections. They were classified as Gross Motor Function Classification System level I and II, aged between 3 and 6 years old, with at least below average mentality, and were in mainstream preschool education; the extension of their hemiplegic wrist and metaphalangeal joint was greater than 10 degrees.
Exclusion Criteria:
Children were excluded if they (a) could not understand or cooperate with the CIMT program, (b) had joint contracture of an upper limb, and (c) could not actively extend their hemiplegic wrist.
